As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Evans owns the following: cow, poultry, pump, but does not own pig, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile. 

Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household mosquito net but does not have electricity, solar power, running water, sewing machine, TV, DVD.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow and  buy materials for constructing a dairy unit.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy tea tree seedlings for the business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To cultivate the farm to allow more planting.

loans.name: Alianca

texts.en:
Alianca is 27 years old and married, and her husband is a driver. She has a kiosk in front of her house. She is taking a $1,000 loan from TRM (Tuba Rai Metin) to improve her business. She opened her kiosk in 2010 with her own woking capital of $300. 

She is living in a town with her family. Her house is made of bricks and zinc for the roof. She is making a good income, and her husband is also generating some income for her family.

She is happy with the TRM program because the repayment is monthly, and she has time to do her business.

loans.use: to buy sugar, coffee, oil, biscuits, fish canes, noodles, detergent and soft drinks.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy additional supplies for weaving.

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
Angela (pictured on the left with her husband and their two daughters), a Tlaxcalan beekeeper, has a diverse backyard farm she would like to invest in. After learning about biodigesters, she decided to invest in a 6-cubic-meter Sistema Biobolsa biodigester. Using the waste from her sheep, cows and pigs, she will generate renewable energy in the form of clean-burning biogas to displace the LP gas she currently uses. Additionally, she will obtain a potent, organic fertilizer to use on her crops. 

Her investment will allow her to save money by turning waste into multiple resources. Her Kiva loan represents 43 percent of the total cost of her Sistema Biobolsa biodigester.

loans.use: to purchase a 6-cubic-meter Sistema Biobolsa biodigester.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase beehives and pay for their colonization.

loans.name: Buena Fe 1, 2 7 3 Group

texts.en:
Yusleny is the coordinator of her group, La Buena Fe ("Good Faith") 1, 2 & 3. This group is located in the rural areas surrounding La Romana, Dominican Republic, where the sugarcane harvest and tourist industry dominate the economy. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her longtime partner and three children. 

Yusleny has been selling miscellaneous products for around six years. She started out with a small sum her partner gave her. She says that her most difficult challenges are selling her products on credit and then collecting on the credit extended. Despite these difficulties she continues to enjoy doing business.

Yusleny is excited to be taking out her seventh loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use her loan to buy miscellaneous products, especially household and cosmetic products. Yusleny will use her profits to invest in her business and to cover some family expenses. She thanks you all for your support!!!

loans.use: to buy household and cosmetic products.

loans.name: Guida

texts.en:
Guida is 37 years old and married. She has seven children and six of them are in school. She has a kiosk in front of her house. She is taking a 1,000 dollar loan from Tuba Rai Metin. Guida will use the loan to buy some additional supplies to keep in her store such as noodles, soft drinks, biscuits, oil and slippers. She is making a good income from her kiosk. She opened her kiosk in 2003 with her own working capital of 200 dollars.

Guida is living in a simple house made of zinc and palm branch for wall. She also has some animals to sell such as pigs and goats.

loans.use: to buy noodles, soft drinks, biscuits, oil and slippers.

loans.name: 3.9.231.thiệu Dương Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Huệ operates a food stall/restaurant, selling soup. She is requesting a loan to purchase materials to make the processed food to sell.

Huệ is 35 years old and she is married with two children.

Huệ is the group leader of the 3.9.231.Thiệu Dương solidarity group, which consists of three members. Huệ supports two dependents with her business in Thieu Hoa district, a  rural town in Thanh Hoa province.

In 2011, Huệ joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her  business. Huệ has successfully repaid three loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

Huệ has been involved in this business for more than 10 years.

One of the most critical business difficulties that concerns her is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Huệ hopes to remodel her house, to make enough money to provide for her kids, and to be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business.

loans.use: to purchase materials to make processed food to sell.

loans.name: 3.13.232.thiệu Đô Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Êm operates a food stall/restaurant, selling snacks. She is requesting a loan to purchase materials to make the processed food to sell.

Êm is 54 years old, and she is married with one child.

Êm is the group leader of the 3.13.232.Thiệu Đô solidarity group, which consists of four members. She lives and works in Thieu Hoa district, a rural area in Thanh Hoa province, with no dependents because her child is grown up.

In 2011, Êm joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her  business. Êm has successfully repaid two loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Êm has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. One of the most critical business difficulties that concerns her is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Êm hopes for her business to do well, to maintain its success, and to be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business.

loans.use: to purchase materials to make the processed food to sell.

loans.name: Casilda

texts.en:
Casilda is 34 years old and is married. She has two children, both of whom are in school. She has a kiosk in front of her house which she opened in 2002 with her own working capital of $50. 

She is one of TRM's (Tuba Rai Metin) good clients, having applied for a loan last year which she paid on time. She is taking her second loan of $1,000 to buy additional supplies, such as soft drinks, salt, sugar, coffee and hard drinks, to sell in her store.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks, salt, sugar, coffee and hard drinks to resell.

loans.name: Jacinta

texts.en:
Jacinta is 28 years old, and she is married. She has four children; three of them are in school. She opened her restaurant in 2008 with her own working capital. 

She is applying for $1,000 from Tuba Rai Metin. She will use the loan to buy rice, fish, meat, soft drinks and hard drinks to serve to people who come to her restaurant. She also has a farm to cultivate corn, bananas and pumpkins. She is making a good income from her restaurant.

loans.use: to buy rice, fish, meat, soft drinks and hard drinks.

loans.name: Luisito

texts.en:
This is Luisito, 59, a resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. He is married to Marita, his business partner, and is a father to their children. He, together with his wife and children, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, he is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Luisito is a butcher. He buys live hogs, slaughters them then sells them. He has a little stall beside his house where he sells pork. He ensures the quality of the pork that he sells. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. He earns a minimum of 1,500 PHP (Philippines pesos) in sales every day.

To help him continue operations of his business, he is requesting a 30,000 PHP loan. He will be utilizing the loan to buy additional pigs. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business. 

Luisito hopes for a good life. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week, and this is where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for more hogs for his business.

loans.name: Joy

texts.en:
Joy, 32 years old, is a resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Walden, a driver and a mother to their child. She and her husband manage their household while operating the business. She is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Joy operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is a retail store that sells inexpensive items, often with a single price for all items in the store. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns income by buying supplies at wholesale prices and selling items individually. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php500 in sales every day.

She is requesting a Php 12,000 loan to help her continue in the operation of her business. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects an expansion in her business income as she enlarges her business. 

Joy hopes her variety store will go a long way and dreams to give her child a good education. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her life and business every week and to also draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and the Word of God she studies.

All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to buy grocery items, toiletries and beverages to resell.

loans.name: Julmira

texts.en:
Julmira is 28 years old and is married. She has a child that is still under age. Julmira operates a kiosk in front of her house. She also raises animals, such as pigs, goats and chickens, in her house that she can sell to generate some income.

She is taking a loan of $1,000 from Tuba Rai Metin. She will use the loan to buy some additional supplies to keep in her store, such as oil, detergent, noodles, sugar and coffee.

loans.use: to buy oil, detergent, noodles, sugar and coffee to resell.

loans.name: 3.9.230.thiệu Dương Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Bảy has a retail business selling dry food. She is requesting a loan to purchase vegetables to sell.

Bảy is 22 years old and she is married with two children. She is the group leader of the 3.9.230.Thiệu Dương solidarity group, which consists of seven members. Bảy supports two dependents with her business in Thieu Hoa district, a rural town in Thanh Hoa province.

In 2011, Bảy joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her  business. Bảy has successfully repaid three loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. She has been involved in this business for five years. One of the most critical business difficulties that concerns her is the lack of skills.

With her business profit, Bảy hopes to make enough money to provide for her kids, to buy land of her own, and to be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business.

loans.use: to purchase vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Candelaria

texts.en:
Candelaria is 43 years old, is married and has eight children. Three of her children are in school. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. 

Candelaria has a trisikad transportation business in the Philippines. Candelaria requested a PHP 14,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy additional trisikads.

Candelaria has been in this business for three years. In the future, Candelaria would like to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional trisikads.

loans.name: 3.9.229. Thiệu Dương Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Phẩm has a manufacturing business knitting. She is requesting a loan to purchase baby poultry to raise and sell in the future.

Phẩm is 57 years old and is married with two children. She is the group leader of the 3.9.229. Thiệu Dương solidarity group, which consists of four members. Phẩm supports no dependents with her business in Thieu Hoa district, a rural town in Thanh Hoa province.

In 2010, Phẩm joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. She has successfully repaid three loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. She has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. One of the most critical business difficulties that concerns her is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Phẩm hopes for her business to do well, to maintain a successful business, and to be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business.

loans.use: to purchase baby poultry to raise and sell in the future.

loans.name: Crisencio

texts.en:
This is Crisencio, 34, resident of Silang, Cavite Philippines. He is married to Marilou, is self employed and father to their children. At this time, he is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Crisencio oversees the operations of their Jeepney (* see footnote) transportation business. He has been in this business for twelve years now. They have one Jeep that carries up to sixteen passengers to their destinations within the community. He earns from the boundary (daily quota) their driver achieves everyday. Their regular passengers and customers are from the local community. He earns a minimum of 1,000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in boundary every day.

To help him continue the operations of his business, he is requesting a PHP 30,000 loan. He will be utilizing the loan to maintain his Jeepney unit. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business.  

Crosencio dreams of having more jeepneys and hopes to have a good life. He meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his life and business every week and there he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies. 

*-Jeepneys are the most popular means of public transportation in the Philippines. They were originally made from US military jeeps left over from World War II and are known for their flamboyant decoration and crowded seating. Filipino ingenuity, however, managed to see this vehicle as an opportunity to earn, and modified the Jeep into a 20-seater jeepney, open enough to provide adequate ventilation, sturdy for everyday travel, and cheap enough to buy and maintain. They have become a ubiquitous symbol of Philippine culture. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for the spare parts and maintenance of their jeepney unit.

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
This is Julieta, 38, resident of Silang, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Victor and a mother to their children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.  

Julieta has a business, where she caters for party needs, especially kids parties. She offers almost everything that a kid’s party needs. From balloons to souvenirs and party poppers. Most of the things needed are part of a package, which customers only need to choose from. Her customers are the people in the community and those being referred by her friends.

To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy the things needed for a party like party poppers, balloons, hats, souvenirs, etc. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Julieta dreams of having more branches in other places and hopes that her children will finish their studies. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and there she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for party materials like party poppers, balloons, hats, souvenirs, etc needed in her business.

loans.name: Bunna

texts.en:
Bunna is 44 years old. She is married and resides with four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia. 

She has been involved in cultivating rice and fattening up animals for more than ten years, earning approximately $3 daily. Her husband helps her run the business. 

One of her children is employed in a garment factory and earns about $3 per day. In order to improve her family’s finances, Bunna is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase rice for resale. By doing so, she can earn additional income to support the family. 

In the future, she would like to run a rice mill and help her children earn a bachelor degree. Moreover, she hopes to rebuild her house to make it much stronger to provide better living conditions for her family.

loans.use: to purchase rice for resale

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia is 28 years old and she is married. She is taking a loan from Tuba Rai Metin to improve her business. 

She has a kiosk in front of her house and is making a good income from it. She opened her kiosk 1 year ago with her own working capital of $ 300. 

She is happy with TRM, who offered her a loan and she will continue to apply for loans after she finishes this one. 

She will use the loan to buy some additional supplies to keep in her store, such as noodles, oil, slippers, candles, sugar, coffee and rice.

loans.use: to buy noodles, oil, slippers, candles, sugar, coffee and rice.

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
This is Lolita. She previously accessed an 30,000 PHP loan, which she used to buy spare parts and cover the maintenance costs of her Internet cafe/computer shop. Her earning has been a big help to the education of her children and in their personal, household and business expenditures. 

She and her husband, a tricycle operator, work hard to provide income for their family. They have been getting income from their tricycle for eleven years now.

She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan for her to buy parts and cover the maintenance costs of her Internet cafe/computer shop. The profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain their daily needs and the educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Lolita hopes to expand her business and dreams of giving her children a good education and a good future. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for the additional computer parts and supplies needed in her business.

loans.name: 03-05-023-Quảng Hưng Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Hồng has a retail business selling dry food. She is requesting a loan to purchase candy, biscuits, sugar, milk, etc to resell and to purchase chickens and ducks to raise .

Hồng is 30 years old and she is married with two children. Hồng is the group leader of the 03-05-023-Quảng Hưng solidarity group, which consists of 6 six members. She lives and works in Thanh Hoa city, a semi-urban area in Thanh Hoa province, with two dependents

In 2004, Hồng joined the Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. Hồng has successfully repaid four loans from the Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Hồng has been involved in this business for five years.

The main hardship that Hồng faces in her business is the lack of capital. With her business profit, Hồng hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, for her business to do well and to maintain a successful business.

loans.use: to purchase candy, biscuits, sugar, milk, etc to resell and to purchase chickens and ducks to raise

loans.name: Alma

texts.en: Alma is a 31-year-old married woman from Getafe, Bohol. She has two children a boy of 12 years and a 10-year-old girl. She is engaged in sari-sari or variety store business for three years now. Her monthly income is PHP 4,000. The general store is the source of her income. Alma is requesting a loan to buy additional items like canned goods, noodles, toiletries, sugar, coffee, soft drinks, and beverages for her store. Through this loan, she will be able to buy all this items and attract the customers in her local community. In the future, Alma hopes to expand her business and gain more profit to sustain the needs of her children in schooling and her family.

loans.use: to buy additional items like canned goods, noodles, toiletries, sugar, coffee, soft drinks and beverages for her general store.

loans.name: Altantsetseg

texts.en:
Mrs.Altantsetseg is a 47-year-old widow, who lives with her two daughters in Ger in Arhangai province of Mongolia. Her daughters, Hajidmaa, age 20 and Hajidsuren, age 19 are university students. 

The borrower has been running an organic dairy products business from the rental counter of a local market since 2005. She has built a close relationship with her customers and herders over the years. 

She is now requesting 1,500,000 MNT to purchase a large amount of organic dairy products to sell to local customers at her rental counter. She is a hardworking and diligent woman.

loans.use: to purchase large amounts of organic dairy products to sell to local customers at her rental counter

loans.name: Vecinas Unidas Group

texts.en:
Regina is the coordinator of her group, Vecinas Unidas (United Neighbors). This group is located in the lush, rugged Samana peninsula, an area with a nascent tourism industry, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity is unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple, rented structure with her long-term partner and two children.

Regina is excited to be taking her eighth loan with Kiva partner, Esperanza, after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling jewelry by purchasing earrings, necklaces and bracelets for her store. 

She will use the profits to provide for her family and to save. She will also save towards her dream of building her own home. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy jewelry

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence is a married woman. She has 4 children. She describes herself to be very ambitious woman. She operates a retail business where she sells cereals. She has been involved in this business for 8 years. Her business is located at a busy market and her primary customers are local residents. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds for improving the business. She will use the 21,000 KES loan to buy a water tank which will be used by her six family members for household chores. Her business goal is to improve the business within 5 years. This is her second loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy a water tank

loans.name: Constance

texts.en:
Constance is applying for another loan to expand her existing business, selling building materials in her hardware store. She says that her business is doing very well as a result of her determination and the support of loans. 

This is Constance's third loan with Kiva and she plans to buy bags of cement and other building materials. She is grateful to Kiva and Yehu for the support. Her aim is to remain in business so that she can have a prosperous future.

loans.use: to buy bags of cement and other building materials.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah lives in Montserrado County, where there is the capital city of Liberia, well-known as the commercial city of Liberia. She is 40 years old, married and has four children between the ages of seven and 22 years old who are in school and live at home.

For the past ten years she has been selling charcoal in her community, but now she is selling slippers from a table in the local market. She started this business with the help of her mother and learned this way of selling from her. She likes her business because it gives her profit. She is requesting a loan to buy more slippers for her business. She wants to get more money to educate her children and build a house.

loans.use: to buy more slippers for her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase bee hives and pay for their colonization.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase bee hives and pay for their colonization.

loans.name: Charlene

texts.en:
This is Charlene. She previously accessed a 50,000 PHP loan that she used to buy RTW products and merchandise items to expand her product inventory. Her earnings were a big help for the education of her children and in their personal, house hold and business expenditures. She has had this business for five years and it continues to grow.  She and her husband are working hard to provide income for their family.

She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan to buy different products like bed sheets, curtains and other items. Her profits from her business will definitely help her to sustain their daily needs and educational expenses of her children. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Charlene hopes her business will keep on growing and dreams that her children will finish their studies. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional stocks of merchandise like bed sheets and curtains needed in her business.

loans.name: Brown

texts.en:
Brown is a resident of Kongowea, Kenya. He is a married father of three school-going children. He owns a retail shop, mainly selling tea leaves, a business he has run for four years. He is also employed as a public transport vehicle driver.

Brown was introduced to Milango by his friends and is applying for a loan of 31,500 Kenya shillings to buy tea leaves to sell. Despite the challenge of bad debts, he is determined to grow the business to wholesale. Brown will use the extra income from the loan to improve the living standards of his family.

loans.use: To buy tea leaves to sell.

loans.name: Honeylin

texts.en:
Honeylin is a 26-year--old married woman from Talibon, Bohol. She has two children, a boy and a girl. The oldest is 7 year old and the youngest is 3 months old. She has engaged in a fishing business together with her husband for 5 years now. She earns 3,000PHP monthly. This is the source of her income.
Honeylin is requesting a loan to buy new fishing nets. With the help of this loan, she will be able to have a good catch and sell it.
In the future, Honeylin hopes to expand her business and to continue to meet the needs of her family.

loans.use: to buy new fishing nets.

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma is 54 years old and married with 10 children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Elma is borrowing PHP 10000 through NWTF to purchase additional feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Elma has been raising pigs for 4 years and also earns additional income from farming rice.
She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Abena

texts.en:
Abena lives together with the husband ; she cooks rice and fish stew for sale at Putubiuw, near Cape Coast. She is married and has five children. 

In front of Abena is the raw rice that she uses in preparing her food for sale.  

She has been in this business for 12 years; she uses her income to support her husband in feeding their children. 

Abena will use her loan to purchase bags of rice and fish to cook, and then sell.  With the new profit,  Abena plans to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase bags of rice and fish to cook and sell.

loans.name: Syrga

texts.ru: Сырга – 43 – летняя фермерша, живущая на юге Кыргызстана. Замужем и имеет 4 детей. Сырга со своей семьей занимается животноводством. Сырга начала этот бизнес более 20 лет назад, купив на накопленные деньги одного барашка она сумела развить очень хорошее и развивающиеся хозяйство. Прибыль от бизнеса помогла Сырге покрывать ежедневные расходы семьи. В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Сырга обратилась в компанию «Бай – Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) на покупку скота для откорма. На доходы от кредита, Саргы планирует дальнейшее увеличение поголовья скота, а в бдущем – устроить своих детей.
texts.en: Syrga is a 43 year old farmer who lives on the south of Kyrgyzstan. She is married and has four children. Syrga is doing animal husbandry with her family. She started this business over 20 years ago by using her savings to buy one lamb and was able to build a well growing business. The profit from the business helps Syrga to cover her daily family expenses. With the goal to further grow her business Syrga has come to Bai Tushum and Partners for a loan in the amount of 100,000 som (KGS) to buy cattle for feeding. Syrga plans to use the profit from the loan to further increase the headcount of livestock and in the future to help her children get settled.

loans.use: to purchase livestock.

loans.name: Jessie

texts.en:
Jessie is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a retailing business in the Philippines.

She is borrowing PHP 9000 through NWTF to buy additional vegetables to sell at her retailing business.

Jessie has been in this business for 10 years. Jessie earns additional income from a coffee shop.
Jessie has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy additional vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Mwanakombo

texts.en:
Mwanakombo is a 29-year-old married woman and lives in her own home in Msambweni. For the last one year, she has been rearing chicken in her home.  She describes herself as a very hard-working and entrepreneurial person who always works hard to improve every day. Mwanakombo is requesting for a loan in the amount of Ksh 10,000 to purchase chicks and chicken feeds (concentrates). She plans to expand her poultry house and keep more chickens.

Her dream is to have a more prosperous life.

loans.use: to purchase chicks and chicken feeds(concentrates).

loans.name: Fredrick

texts.en:
Fredrick is 41 years old, married, and blessed with three children aged 12, five and one years. His spouse is a civil servant and supports him in meeting some of their financial needs. Fredrick runs a transport (Matatu) business in Kabarnet town and also runs a retail shop as his second business for the last ten years.
 
Fredrick has borrowed a loan of 70,000 KES. With this loan, he intends to use the whole amount to pay school fees his children.With the anticipated profits he intends to expand his business and service his public service vehicle for better service. 

His future plan is to buy a plot for building business premises and to expand his retail shop.

loans.use: To pay school fees for his children.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John,now 48 years of age, does quarrying business.  He used his previous loan amount to buy a heifer cow to start dairy farming. It has been profitable and has enabled him to provide for the needs of his family, and he was able to pay all the loan amount.

This being his second loan, he plans to use the loan amount to buy another dairy cow and add to his dairy livestock. Due to the growing demand of milk in the town of Ndunyu Njeru, he anticipates he will generate more income with which he will provide basic needs for the family.

John hopes to grow his dairy farming business by supplying milk to various areas of Ndunyu Njeru.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Menzi Ann

texts.en:
As a married parent of one child, Menzi Ann works hard to support her family.

She has a motorcycle transport business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from a general store.  Menzi Ann is borrowing PHP 14000 through NWTF to buy spare parts and other materials for the maintenance of her motorcycle.

Menzi Ann has been sustaining her business activities through her past 8 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy spare parts and other materials for the maintenance of her motorcycle.

loans.name: Matanta

texts.en:
Matanta is 27 years old, single and supports his mother. He has reared steers and heifers for fattening for the last 10 years, making a monthly income of  20,000 KES.

He has applied for his second loan of 40,000 KES from KADET Ltd. and he plans to purchase more heifers for fattening and to later resell at higher profits. 

The anticipated profits will help get more land on lease for grazing. His future dreams are to build a residential house and for business success.

loans.use: to purchase heifers for fattening

loans.name: Cirilo

texts.en:
Cirilo is a 44-year-old married man from Talibon, Bohol. He has three children. The oldest is 21 years old and the youngest is 12 years old. He has been engaged in a motorcycle transport business for 10 years now. This is the source of his income.
Cirilo is requesting a loan to pay for the maintenance of his motorcycle. With the help of this loan, his motorcycle will always be in good condition to carry the maximum capacity of passengers.
In the future, Cirilo hopes to expand his business and to be successful.

loans.use: to pay for the maintenance of his motorcycle.

loans.name: Emmaculate

texts.en: The desire to get ahead is one of this lady's goals. She has shown a great urge to move forward through enterprising skills. She used her previous loan to invest in her shop. She is now asking for another loan to invest in her new cosmetics shop, which is well-stocked. Her aim is to see it grow further. Since she received her previous loan, she has been little by little improving her home. This loan will allow her to add stock of cosmetics and other beauty products since her inventory has gone down.

loans.use: to add stock of cosmetics and other beauty products.

loans.name: Mwanasha

texts.en: Mwanasha is a very hardworking woman who is dedicated to her job. She is happy since her business is doing well. She attributes this to the support she got from her previous loan from Kiva lenders. Thanks for this support; it has made her grow her business little by little. Today, Mwanasha is asking for another loan that will enable her expand her business, selling kerosene. The loan will be used to buy gallons of kerosene to sell.She is grateful to Kiva lenders for their support!

loans.use: to buy gallons of kerosene to sell.

loans.name: Lovella

texts.en:
This is Lovella. She previously accessed a 25,000 PHP loan that she used to purchase additional stocks of supplies and products for her grocery store. Her earnings were a big help for her children’s education and also in their personal, house hold and business expenditures. She has this business for just a year but her business is continuously growing. She and her husband are working hard to provide income for their everyday expenses. She also has electronic loading for additional income.

She would like to apply for another 40,000 PHP loan for her to buy large amounts of grocery items. The more items displayed at the store the better. The more items she has to sell will result in a better profit. Her profits from the business will definitely help sustain her family’s daily needs and children’s education expense. She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart.

Lovella hopes her business will grow in the coming years and dreams of being able to give her family a good future and high quality education through all her hard work. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for large amount of grocery items needed in her business.

loans.name: 03-04-073-Quảng Hưng Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Dung works in agriculture, farming poultry and cattle. She is requesting a loan to purchase chickens, pigs and ducks to raise and resell.

Dung is 36 years old and she is married with 3 children.
Dung is the group leader of the 03-04-073-Quảng Hưng solidarity group, which consists of 3 members.

She lives and works in Thanh Hoa city, a semi-urban area in Thanh Hoa province, with 3 dependents
In 2010, Dung joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. Dung has successfully repaid 4 loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

Dung has been involved in this business for 5 years.
The main harship that Dung faces in her business is the lack of capital.

With her business profit, Dung hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, for her business to do well, and to be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business.

loans.use: to purchase chickens, pigs and ducks to raise and resell.

loans.name: Elma

texts.en:
Elma is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a restaurant in the Philippines.
She is borrowing PHP 20000 through NWTF to buy ingredients for her restaurant.
Elma has been in this business for 10 years. Elma also earns income from selling vegetables and raising pigs.

Elma has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts and with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for her food stall.

loans.name: 03-04-002-Quảng Hưng Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Hiền has a retail business selling drinks. She is requesting a loan to purchase materials to support her drink service.

Hiền is 45 years old and is married with 2 children.
Hiền is the group leader of the 03-04-002-Quảng Hưng solidarity group, which consists of 3 members.

She lives and works in Thanh Hoa city, a semi-urban area in Thanh Hoa province, with 1 dependent.
In 2005, Hiền joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. Hiền has successfully repaid 4 loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

Hiền has been involved in this business for 6 years.
The main harship that Hiền faces in her business is the lack of capital.
With her business profit, Hiền hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, for her business to do well, and to build a new house.

loans.use: to purchase materials to support her drink service.

loans.name: Desarrollo Comunitaria 1, 2, 3 & 5 Group

texts.en:
Apolonia is the coordinator of her group, Desarrollo Comunitario (Community Development). Her group is located in the lush, rugged Samana peninsula, an area with a tourism industry. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long-term partner and three children.

Apolonia is excited to be taking her 16th loan with Kiva partner, Esperanza, after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling clothing by purchasing bedding set, shirts, pants, skirts and bracelets in the capital and then selling them at profit in her community. Apolonia will use her profits to invest in remodeling her home as well as purchasing school supplies for her children. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: to purchase clothes, bedding set and bracelets to sell in her area.

loans.name: Narcita

texts.en:
Narcita is a 69-year-old married woman from Talibon, Bohol. She has three grown children. She has been engaged in a food vending business for 13 years now. She sells viand, cooked rice, meat, and chicken. This is the source of her income.
Narcita is requesting a loan for additional capital in her business. Through this loan, she will be able to finance the needs and supplies that are needed for the productivity of her business.
In the future, Narcita hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy supplies for her food vending business.

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
Analyn is 22 years old and married with 2 children.
She earns a living by farming rice in the Philippines. Analyn is borrowing PHP 21000 through NWTF to purchase fertilizers and other farm equipment for her business.
Analyn has been farming rice for 3 years and also earns additional income from buying and selling charcoal.
She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm equipment for farming rice.

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina works hard to support her family. Cristina is married and buys and sells rice in the Philippines.
Cristina requested a PHP 10000 loan through NWTF to buy additional sacks of rice to sell.
Cristina has been in this business for 3 years now.
In the future, Cristina would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional sacks of rice to sell.

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a restaurant in the Philippines.
She is borrowing PHP 15000 through NWTF to purchase additional ingredients for her restaurant.
Merlyn has been in this business for 10 years. Merlyn earns additional income from a repair shop and raising pigs.
Merlyn has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts and with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional ingredients for her restaurant.

loans.name: Burul

texts.ru: Бурул 53 года, замужем, воспитала 7 детей. В 2012 году, в поисках источника финансирования своей семьи, Бурул начала свой бизнес в разведении скота .Использовав стартовую сумму в 50,000 сом (KGS) на покупку скота, Бурул сумела развить свое хозяйство, с ежемесячной прибылью в сумме около 10,000 сом (KGS). На сегодняшний день, в ее хозяйстве имеется развитое хозяйство. В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Бурул обратилась в компанию «Бай – Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS) на покупку овец на откорм. В ближайшее время, при помощи доходов от кредита, Бурул планирует увеличивать поголовье скота.
texts.en: Burul is 53 years old, she is married and has raised seven children. In 2012 Burul started her business by breeding cattle while looking for a source of income to finance her family. She used a starting capital of 50,000 som (KGS) to buy cattle and was able to grow her business with a monthly profit in the amount of 10,000 KGS. Today she has a well developed business. Burul has come to Bai Tushum and Partners for a loan in the amount 50,000 som to buy sheep for feeding with the goal to further grow her business. In the near future with the help of the income from the loan Burul plans to increase the headcount of livestock.

loans.use: to purchase sheep.

loans.name: Jessica

texts.en:
This is Jessica, 38, and a resident of Intramuros, Manila, Philippines. She is married to Samuel, a vendor, and a mother to their children. She, together with her husband, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Jessica sells mangoes. She has a little cart that she uses to roam around their community to sell them. There are also times especially at night where she just stays in one location and can wait for customers. She also sells soft brooms. She earns a minimum of Php400 in sales every day.
To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 35, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more mangoes.  She will also use the loan to buy soft brooms.

Jessica hopes to expand her business and dreams that her children will finish their studies. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy more mangoes.

loans.name: Martinha

texts.en: Martinha is 49 years old. She is married and she has three children, two of which are studying in the elementary school. She is requesting a loan to purchase some additional items including sugar, cigarettes and biscuits.  She lives in a house made of palm branches and zinc for the roof. She started her business in 2005 with working capital of $300.00.  She wants to open a big store and build a good house for her family in the future.

loans.use: to buy items for her general store.

loans.name: Eleciana

texts.en:
Eleciana is a hardworking entrepreneur who sells meat in the Philippines.

She is borrowing PHP 12000 through NWTF to purchase additional meat to sell.

Eleciana has been in this business for 4 years. Eleciana earns additional income from food vending.
Eleciana has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to build and expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional meat to sell in her meat stand.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn works hard to support her family. She is married and has had a rice-selling business in the Philippines for 3 years now.

Evelyn has requested a loan of 18,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) through NWTF to buy additonal sacks of rice to sell. In the future, she would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additonal sacks of rice to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy clothes for her clothes-selling business

loans.name: Evans

texts.en:
Evans lives in Kitale, a maize-growing area of Kenya. He has four children and has been a farmer for 16 years. His primary income sources are milk, eggs, crops and other personal business activities.

Evans says that the most enjoyable thing about farming is feeding and milking his dairy cows, while his biggest challenge is the diseases they can catch. He has given the animals on the farm the name "Mrembo". He will use the loan of 52,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) from Juhudi kilimo to buy and insure another dairy cow.

Evans chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan because the agency gives loans to small scale farmers like him. He learnt about their loans through Juhudi's required micro-finance training session. The agency offers reasonable loan terms that can run up to two years.

When asked how this loan benefit his family, Evans replied 'I will be able to feed my family and take the children to school.' His highest monthly expense is school fees.

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated and changes in living standards based on loans are measured. Evans owns cows and poultry but does not own pigs, a pump, a bicycle, a motorcycle or an automobile. His household has mosquito nets but does not have electricity, solar power, running water, a sewing machine, a TV or a DVD player.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna is 53 years old and married with four children, one of whom is in school.

Edna is in the agricultural business. She raises pigs in the Philippines. Edna has requested a PHP 28,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Edna has been raising pigs for three years now. She has borrowed seven times in the past from NWTF to sustain her business.

In the future, Edna would like to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice sells apples at Elmina. She has received schooling through junior high school.  She is single and has two children. Beatrice has been selling apples for some time now. She is responsible for paying to support herself and pay her children's school fees. Her loan will be used to buy more apples to sell in the market. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to develop her business further and possibly increase the variety of fruits she sells.

loans.use: to buy more apples to sell in the market.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria is married and has 2 children. She has received schooling through senior high school. Gloria sells local juice drinks and fish at Elmina, which she has done for some time now. Her husband is a net owner that fishes in the community. Gloria uses her income to support her husband with their family's general expense. Gloria will use the loan to purchase more ingredients to make her fresh drinks and buy more fish to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Gloria plans to increase her capital base and grow her business.

loans.use: to purchase more ingredients to make her fresh drinks and buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more rice and tea to sell

loans.name: Araba

texts.en: Araba is married and has six children. Araba sells cosmetics, ladies' wear and underwear, which she has done for three years. Her husband is a mason. Araba uses her income to assists her husband in the general upkeep of their family. Araba will use the loan to purchase cosmetics, ladies' wear and underwear to sell. With the new profits, Araba plans to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase cosmetics, ladies' wear and underwear to sell.

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is a taxi driver at Santrokofi, Hohoe. Richard has received a junior high school education.  He is married and has two children. His wife is a petty trader. Richard has been a driver for five years now. He is responsible for paying his children's fees and cares for the home. His loan will be used to repair and change some damaged parts of the car for it to be operational. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to save to acquire a mini bus for a longer journey.

Richard is the male in the red shirt and the other person is a passenger.

loans.use: to repair and change some damaged parts of his taxi

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
As a married mother of three children, Elizabeth works hard to support her family.

She has a fishing business in the Philippines. Elizabeth is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to buy a fishing net and other equipment for her fishing business.

Elizabeth has been sustaining her business activities through her past two loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy a fishing net and other equipment.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence is single and has 4 children. She has received schooling through a trade school level. Florence sells local drinks at Elmina, which she has done for some time now. Florence uses her income to support herself and her children. Florence will use the loan to purchase more ingredients to make fresh drinks. With the new profits from her expanded business, Florence plans to expand her drink selling enterprise.

loans.use: to purchase more ingredients to make fresh drinks.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret sells provisions at Elmina. Margaret has received schooling through junior high school.  She is single and has 2 children. Margaret has been selling provisions in the community for some time now. She is responsible for paying to support herself and her children. Her loan will be used to buy a greater quantity and variety of provisions to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to expand her provisions shop.

loans.use: to buy a greater quantity and variety of provisions to sell.

loans.name: Bright Kwasi

texts.en: Bright Kwasi is single and has one child. He has received schooling through senior high school. Bright Kwasi sells beverages at Elmina, which he has done for some time now. He uses his income to support himself and his child. He will use the loan to purchase a greater quantity and variety of drinks to sell. With the new profits from his expanded business, he plans to develop his drink selling spot further.

loans.use: to purchase a greater quantity and variety of drinks to sell.

loans.name: Jackson

texts.en:
Jackson lives in the Kitale area of Kenya, which has a high regional output of maize. He has two children. He has operated a dairy business for six years. His primary income sources are milk and eggs. The loan of 62,400 KES from Juhudi Kilimo will help him buy and insure a dairy cow.

Jackson says what is most enjoyable about farming is, "feeding cows!" His biggest challenges are "diseases and expensive dairy feed." Animals on the farm have been given the names of "Maua."

When Jackson was asked why he chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, he replied: "Because it gives loans to farmers to boost their production and improve their livelihoods." When asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session, Jackson replied, "the importance of directing funds to the intended projects."

His highest monthly expenses are his children's school fees. When asked how this loan will benefit his family, Jackson replied, "My children will get a proper education and food."

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Jackson owns a cow and poultry but does not own a pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle or automobile. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household a mosquito net but does not have electricity, solar power, running water, sewing machine, TV or DVD.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient and keeping costs down.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Jamiyla

texts.ru:
Для Жамили это третий кредит от КИВА. Ей очень сильно понравилась данная программа, данный проект существенно улучшил благосостояние её семьи. Еще ей понравились льготы который предоставляет банк "Бай Тушум и партнеры" для заемщиков данного проекта. Она хотела бы поблагодарить всех кто её поддерживает и помогает преодолеть все жизненные заботы.
В этот раз Жамиля обратилась в Микрофинансовый банк "Бай Тушум и партнеры" за кредитом в размере 100,000 KGS. На заемные средства она планирует приобрести 2 коровы, тем самым сможет увеличить выручку от продажи молока.
texts.en:
For Jamiyla this is the third Kiva loan.  She really liked this loan program as it substantially improved welfare of her family. Jamiyla also liked discounts provided by "Bai Tushum and Partners" for borrowers of this loan product.  She would like to thank everyone who supports her and helps overcome life's challenges. 

This time Jamiyla applied to Microfinance bank "Bai Tushum and Partners" for a loan of 100,000 KGS.  She's planning to use the loan proceeds to buy 2 cows, and thus increase her income from sales of milk.

loans.use: to purchase two milk cows

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose lives in the Kitale area of Kenya, which lies in the northern part of the Rift Valley. She has two children and has been doing this work for 13 years.  Her primary income sources are milk, eggs, and crops.

She stated what is most enjoyable about farming: 'Feeding dairy cows!' Her biggest challenge is 'Diseases.' Animals on the farm have been given the names of 'Bahati and Lelmet". She will channel the loan of 41,600 acquired from Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow.

Rose was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied: 'Because they give loans to farmers and I am a farmer who needs some finances.'  This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: 'They are short term loans.'

Her highest monthly expense is school fees. When asked 'How will this loan benefit your family?', Rose replied 'I will be able to generate income from the sale of milk to support my family and educate my children.'

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Rose owns the following: 'cow, poultry' but does not own 'pig, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, or automobile'. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household 'mosquito net' but does not have 'electricity, solar power, running water, sewing machine, TV, DVD'.

Note: To create this loan profile, Juhudi Kilimo used a mobile device to gather information in the field and send the data to a central online repository, thus reducing paper use, making the process more efficient, and keeping costs down.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Hazel

texts.en:
Hazel is married with two children. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. Hazel is 24 years old and has one child currently going to school.

Hazel has a "buy and sell rice" business in the Philippines. Hazel requested a PHP 17,000 loan amount through NWTF to buy sacks of rice to sell.

Hazel has been in this business for three years. In the future, Hazel would like to save enough to provide and secure financial stability for her family.

loans.use: to buy sacks of rice to sell

loans.name: Epifania

texts.en:
Epifania works hard to support her family. She is married and has a fishing business in the Philippines.

Epifania requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy a new engine for her fishing boat. She has been in this business for ten years.

In the future, Epifania would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy a new engine for her fishing boat.

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline is 33 years old, married and has 3 children are all in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Evangeline has a meat vending business in the Philippines. Evangeline requested a 18000 PHP loan amount through NWTF to buy more meat to sell in her food stall.

Evangeline has been in this business for four years. In the future, Evangeline would like to save enough money to afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more meat to sell in her food stall.

loans.name: Evengeline

texts.en:
Evangeline is 43 years old. She is married and has seven children. Two of her children are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. 

Evangeline has a copra business in the Philippines. She requested a 19000 PHP loan amount through NWTF to buy more coconut to make copra.

Evangeline has been in this business for six years. In the future, she would like to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more coconut to make copra.

loans.name: Suryati

texts.en:
Suryati is 41 years old and married to Thomas. They have two children, both of whom go to school. She owns a grocery store and has been running this business for the past five years. The location is 5 km from her house and per day she may get IDR 150,000.  The profits from the business will be used for her family needs and pay her children's education fees.

Suryati requested a IDR 6,000,000 loan through VisionFund Indonesia to pay her children's school fees and to buy noodles, children's snacks, and sugar. She is working diligently even though she has a competitor near her house; she enjoys running this business because she has income as a housewife.

loans.use: to pay her children's school fees and to buy noodles, children's snacks, and sugar.

loans.name: Felisa

texts.en:
Felisa is a 45-year-old married woman from Antequera, Bohol. She has four children. The oldest child is 15 while the youngest is 4. She raises hogs. Her husband is a carpenter. She has been in the hog raising business for eight years. 

Felisa requested a loan of 8,000 PHP to buy additional piglets and feed. In the future, Felisa would like to expand her business to support her family as well as to save for her children's education.

loans.use: to buy additional piglets and feed

loans.name: Rufina

texts.en:
Rufina is a 54-year-old married woman from Maribojoc, Bohol. She has four grown children. She has been engaged in a 'sari-sari' or variety store business for fpir years now. In her store she sells canned goods, toiletries, soft drinks, coconut wine and other beverages. She earns 6,000 PHP per month. This is the source of her income and has to cover other needs of the family.

Rufina is requesting a loan to buy more merchandise to sell. She wants to purchase more items in order to have a lot of stock in her store: snacks, biscuits, sugar, milk, candies and chocolates.

In the future, Rufina hopes to expand her business and earn more profit.

loans.use: to buy more merchandise to sell

loans.name: Book Jom Taiba Mbaye 3 Group

texts.fr: Ceci est un groupement qui rassemble cinq femmes qui  habitent le même village et qui font du commerce de légumes et de produits halieutiques. Elles sont expérimentées car plusieurs d’entre elles ont fait entre 10 et 15 d’activité. Leur présidente, la dame Saly très souriante sur la photo, est âgée de 52 ans, mariée et mère de famille. Avec le crédit qu’elle va recevoir, elle ira acheter des légumes : carottes, navets, aubergines… Elle achètera aussi du poisson fumé et séché, tout cela pour revendre sur le marché local car elle possède une cantine. Elle a une expérience de 10 ans dans ce domaine d’activité. Elle ne reste pas les bras croisés car elle participe à la dépense quotidienne de la famille. Puisqu’elle a une clientèle régulière, elle aimerait acquérir un fond stable afin de pouvoir les satisfaire à temps pour cela elle a besoin de l’appui de l’IMCEC.
texts.en:
This group is made up of five women who all live in the same village and who all buy and sell vegetables and fish products. They have plenty of experience; several of them have been in the business for 10-15 years.

Saly (who is the woman with the big smile in the photo) is the group's president. She is 52 years old, married, and a mother. She will use the loan to buy vegetables: carrots, turnips, eggplant, etc. She will also buy smoked and dried fish. She will then resell her goods at the local market, where she has a food stand.

She has 10 years of experience in this line of business. She works actively to help cover her family's daily expenses. Since she has regular customers, she would like to acquire a stable base so that she can meet the needs of all of her customers. To do so, she requires the assistance of the IMCEC.

loans.use: to buy vegetables and fish products intended for resale

loans.name: Rita

texts.en: Rita is 44 years old and she is married. She has eight children, and seven of them are in school. She has been doing this activity since 2005 with her own working capital of $ 50.00. This is the only income that she can  generate to support her family and let her seven children study. She been making a good income. She will use the loan to buy some additional supplies to bake cakes such as flour, sugar, and many other things.

loans.use: to buy flour, sugar and other things

loans.name: Luzvilla

texts.en:
Luzvilla is 56 years old and married with three children. She earns a living by pig fattening in the Philippines. Luzvilla is borrowing PHP 13,000 through NWTF to purchase additional feed for her business.

Luzvilla has been pig fattening for two years and also earns additional income from raising chickens.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional feed for her business

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
As a married parent of nine children, Maria works hard to support her family.

She has a restaurant business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from raising chickens and pigs and from her general store. Maria is borrowing PHP 24,000 through NWTF to purchase additional ingredients for her restaurant business.

Maria has been sustaining her business activities through her past seven loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream: to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional ingredients for her restaurant

loans.name: Charito

texts.en:
Charito is a 41-year-old married woman from Baclayon, Bohol. She has five children. The oldest child is 20 while the youngest is 7. She is engaged in a "buy and sell" business. She buys and sells Avon products like perfume, lotion, soap, powder and other beauty products. She has been in this business for 10 years. She requested a loan of 18,000 PHP to buy more Avon products and dried fish for retailing. 

In the future, Charito would like to invest in another business to improve their livelihood and also so she could be able to send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy  more Avon products to sell and dried fish for retailing

loans.name: Sebena

texts.en:
Sebena is 36 years old and married, with five children. Sebena works hard to provide for her family. She runs a buy and sell charcoal business in the Philippines and requested a PHP 17,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to buy additional sacks of charcoal to sell.

Sebena has borrowed and paid six loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the buy and sell charcoal business for three years and also earns income from a sari sari store and buying and selling rice and vegetables. Sebena aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional sacks of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Geraline

texts.en:
Geraline is 31 years old, married, and has three children who attend school. She has a fishing business in the Philippines, which she has been doing for two years. 

Geraline is requesting a loan from NWTF for 10,000 PHP, which she will use to buy fishing net and other equipment.  In the future, Geraline would like to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase fishing net and other equipment.

loans.name: Lady Mae

texts.en:
Lady Mae is 34 years old, married, and has two children, both of whom are in school. She is a very hard-working entrepreneur. 

Lady Mae has a variety store business in the Philippines. Lady Mae requested a PHP 13,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to buy more items, like shampoo, snack food, and other groceries.

Lady Mae has been in this business for five years. In the future, Lady Mae would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more items for her variety store, like shampoo, snack food, and other groceries.

loans.name: Gelasia

texts.en: Gelasia is a 61-year-old married woman from Panglao, Bohol. She has 12 grown children. She has operated a motorcycle transportation business in her community for seven years. Her husband is a farmer. She requested a loan of 18,000 PHP to pay for fuel and maintenance, such as oil changes and tires. She needs to perform this maintenance in order to continue to serve her customers. In the future, Gelasia would like to invest in other ventures to have a sustainable livelihood while she prepares for retirement.

loans.use: to pay for fuel and maintenance

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en: Teresita is 35 years old, married, and has two children. She earns a living by raising poultry in the Philippines. Teresita is borrowing 20,000 PHP through NWTF to buy additional feed and vitamins for her chicks. Teresita has been in the poultry business for four years and also earns additional income from pig fattening. She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional feed and vitamins for her chicks

loans.name: Isroildjon

texts.ru:
Исроилджон житель города Турсунзаде. Он женат. Ему 35 лет. У него четверо детей. Исроилджон вместе с семьей занимается растениеводством. Он трудолюбивый молодой человек. Исроилджон также зарабатывает строительными работами по найму. 
Исроилджон берет кредит для обработки земли и посева пшеницы. В этой области у него богатый опыт. Он более двадцати лет занимается посевом сельскохозяйственных культур.
texts.en:
Isroildjon lives in the city of Tursun-zoda. He is 35 years old, married, and has four children. Isroildjon and his family are farmers. He is a hard-working young man and also earns an income from working on construction projects.

Isroildjon is taking this loan to cultivate his land and sow wheat. After twenty years of growing crops, he has a wealth of experience in this area.

loans.use: to buy seeds and mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Violet Group

texts.en:
Group Leader Herawati, 38, is married and has two children. Her business is selling mineral water to a large number of taxi drivers in the taxi station in Cimanggis, east of Jakarta. She has been working in this business for two years. It is going well for her thanks to the determination she puts into each day. She is a responsible and determined person, and she supports her family by being this way. She is requesting the loan to purchase boxes of mineral water. She dreams of sending her child to university.

The other group members have a variety of business such as selling cooked food, selling cosmetics, and selling vegetables.

loans.use: to buy boxes of mineral water

loans.name: Ologolimot

texts.en:
Ologolimot has completed paying his previous loan and is now applying for a fourth loan. He plans use the loan amount to prepare the land and buy seedlings and fertilizers for the upcoming planting season. 

Ologolimot is now able to cultivate a larger portion of his land as well as increase the number of animals for fattening and selling. He plans to use the increased proceeds to educate his children as well as improve the family's living standards.

loans.use: to prepare the land and buy seedlings and fertilizers for the upcoming planting season.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia is a married woman from Panglao, Bohol. She has eight grown children. She raises hogs. She has been in the hog-raising business for ten years now. She also engages in the fishing business as her second business.

Lucia requested a loan of PHP 15,000 to buy feed, fish net, and hooks. Through this loan, she will be able to buy the food for her hogs and tools for fishing. In the future, Lucia hopes to expand her business to support her family.

loans.use: to buy feed for her hogs and fish net and hooks for her fishing business.

loans.name: Ma.victoria

texts.en:
Ma.Victoria is 31 years old, married, and has two children, both of whom are in school. Ma.Victoria works very hard to provide for them.

Ma.Victoria runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 12,000 loan through Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. (NWTF) to purchase more groceries to sell.

Ma.Victoria has been in this business for two years and sells a variety of items, such as cooking oil, vegetables, and other groceries. In the future, Ma.Victoria would like to save enough money, so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries to sell in her sari-sari store.

loans.name: Muazam

texts.ru: Муазам проживает в городе Душанбе. Ей 55 лет. У нее двое детей. Уже 4 года как Муазам работает в сфере торговли. Она вместе с мужем на рынке Корвон занимается продажей сезонной одежды. Муазам хочет увеличить товарооборот и получить хорошую прибыль. С этой целью она запрашивает кредит на сумму 3000 долларов для приобретения товаров (одежды всех видов).
texts.en: Muazam lives in the city of Dushanbe. She is 55 years old and has two children. For the past 4 years, Muazam has worked in retail. Together with her husband, she sells seasonal clothing at the Korvon market. Muazam would like to increase her sales volume and make a good profit. To this end, she is requesting a loan of $3000 to purchase new merchandise (clothing of all kinds).

loans.use: to stock up on different types of clothing

loans.name: Mehrbonu

texts.ru: Мехрбону жительница города Душанбе. Она замужем. Ей 35 лет. Мехрбону имеет средне - специальное образование. Она окончила медколледж. Мехрбону шест лет проработала в этой области. Сейчас у Мехрбону собственная торговая точка на оптовом рынке Корвон, где она вместе с мужем продает национальную одежду для невесток, тюбетейки, безрукавки. Мехрбону занята в области торговли уже 10 лет. С целью увеличения товарооборота и расширения своего бизнеса, Мехрбону обратилась за кредитом.
texts.en: Mehrbonu lives in the city of Dushanbe. She is 35 years old and married. Mehrbonu has specialize post-secondary education: she graduated from a medical college and for the next six years worked in this field. Presently, Mehrbonu runs her own retail spot at the wholesale Korvon market, where she and her husband sell traditional bridal clothing, hats, and vests. Mehrbonu has been engaged in retail for 10 years. She has requested a loan in order to increase her sales volume and expand her business.

loans.use: to buy new types of dresses

loans.name: Risper

texts.en:
Risper is a resident of Kongowea, Kenya. She is a single mother of one child. Risper is a clothes seller, a business she has run for eight years. She was introduced to Milango Financial Services by her friend and joined the group in order to access credit for business operations. 

Risper is applying for a loan of KES 15,850 (Kenya shillings) to purchase a new stock of clothes. Despite the challenge of bad debts, Risper looks forward to growing the business into a wholesale business. The extra income will go towards the improvement of the family's living standard.

loans.use: To purchase a new stock of clothes for sale.

loans.name: Vangie

texts.en: Vangie has a fishing business in the Philippines. She is requesting her second loan from NWTF for 11,000 PHP, which she will use to buy fishing net and other equipment for fishing so that she can further build her business.

loans.use: to purchase tools and equipment for fishing.

loans.name: Nataiyuang

texts.en:
Nataiyuang has completed paying her previous loan and has now embarked on a livestock fattening business, in addition to wheat farming. She has managed to join up with a group of other farmers, who together help each other in the animal rearing business.

She will used this loan to increase the number of her animals, as well as to prepare the land for the upcoming planting season.

She hopes to use the proceeds to educate her children and better her family's living standards.

loans.use: to increase the number of her animals and to prepare the land for the upcoming planting season.

loans.name: Mila

texts.en:
As a married parent of 3 children, Mila works hard to support her family. She has a buy-and-sell ready-to-wear clothing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from food vending. 

Mila is borrowing 20000 PHP through NWTF to buy additional stocks of clothing to sell in her business.

Mila has been sustaining her business activities through her past 9 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of building and expanding her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks of ready-to-wear clothing to sell.

loans.name: Evans

texts.en:
Evans is a resident of Kongowea, Kenya. He is a married father of three school-going children. He owns a retail shop, mainly selling tea leaves - a business he has run for five years. He is also employed as a public transport vehicle driver. 

Evans was introduced to Milango by his friends and is applying for a loan of 31,500 Kenyan shillings to buy tea leaves to sell. Despite the challenge of bad debts, he is determined to grow the business to wholesale. 

Evans will use the extra income from the loan to improve the living standards of his family.

loans.use: to buy tea leaves to sell in his shop.

loans.name: Kurash

texts.en:
Kurash is now a father of five children. He has completed paying his previous loan and is now preparing for another planting season. He got a good harvest in the last season and has leased an additional piece of land, on which he plans to plant a variety of crops.

He has acquired another loan from KADET LTD, which will allow him to purchase seedlings and fertilizers, as well as pay for the labour for land ploughing.

He hopes to use the increased proceeds to build a permanent house for the family.

loans.use: to prepare his land and buy chemicals and fertilizer for his wheat farm.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth lives in the Kongowea area of Coast Province, Kenya. She is married and has four children. She owns a retail shop, a business that has been running for six years. She employs two other people in the business.

She learned about Milango through friends who invited her to the group, and she joined with the aim of accessing credit to improve her business operations. Her main business challenges are high transport costs and bad debts.
